comments:
Freshly unzipped eclipse does not find its swt-gtk64 libraries. 
Splash screen pops up, then an error message box (which does look like a GTK 
widget, strange enough), pops up and the error log says: 
 
java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError:  
/opt/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk64_3.0.0/os/linux/amd64/libswt-pi-gtk-3062.so:  
/opt/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk64_3.0.0/os/linux/amd64/libswt-pi-gtk-3062.so: 
cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory 
 
But the library is exactly there, and ldd tells me that there are no 
unsatisfied dependencies in it: 
 
ldd /opt/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk64_3.0.0/os/linux/amd64/libswt-pi-gtk-3062.so 
 
        libgtk-x11-2.0.so.0 => /opt/gnome/lib64/libgtk-x11-2.0.so.0

Created an attachment (id=13353)
eclipse error log

This problem is hapening verbatim on my machine as well.  I also am using Suse
9.1  PRO - 64bit version

Can you start eclipse with:
eclipse -vmargs -verbose
and paste the output here?

- can you run a simple HelloWorld SWT app or does it fail as well?

Created an attachment (id=14000)
eclipse -vmargs -verbose output

eclipse -vmargs -verbose output from the console

At least for my machine.  This output ends with the same error as before:

java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError:
/temp/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk64_3.1.0/os/linux/amd64/libswt-pi-gtk-3101.so:
/temp/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk64_3.1.0/os/linux/amd64/libswt-pi-gtk-3101.so:
cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

OK, I am on personally uncharted territory here.  I have never run any java
program outside of eclipse as a stand alone program.  Not my job :)

So, yes, I will need a little help here:

I 'touch' a file called Main.java
I pasted in your code
I compiled it with the following command:

javac -classpath /temp/swt64/swt.jar Main.java

and I get a class file: Main.class

Then I try to execute this all like this:
java -classpath /temp/swt64/swt.jar -Djava.library.path=/temp/swt64/ main

and I get 
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: main

A little help here and you will have your output.

thanks

You're almost there. Some case sensitive issue. Try this:

java -classpath /temp/swt64/swt.jar -Djava.library.path=/temp/swt64/ Main

Try this:

java -classpath .:/temp/swt64/swt.jar -Djava.library.path=/temp/swt64/ Main

Different :) but still no dice.  I also tried this with the 32bit binaries, and
got the same results

linux:/temp/swt64 # java -classpath .:/temp/swt64/swt.jar
-Djava.library.path=/temp/swt64/ Main
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError:
org/eclipse/swt/internal/gtk/OS
        at org.eclipse.swt.internal.Converter.wcsToMbcs(Converter.java:63)
        at org.eclipse.swt.internal.Converter.wcsToMbcs(Converter.java:54)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.<clinit>(Display.java:118)
        at Main.main(Main.java:6)

Sorry - you also need the swt-pi.jar in the classpath.

Like this:

java -classpath .:/temp/swt64/swt.jar::/temp/swt64/swt-pi.jar -
Djava.library.path=/temp/swt64/ Main

Fixing typo. Like this:

java -classpath .:/temp/swt64/swt.jar:/temp/swt64/swt-pi.jar -
Djava.library.path=/temp/swt64/ Main

OK, now we have it.. running your command on the 32bit swt binaries ran
perfectly, window opened.

AND -- now we have the 64bit-specific error:

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError:
/temp/swt64/libswt-pi-gtk-3062.so: /temp/swt64/libswt-pi-gtk-3062.so: cannot
open shared object file: No such file or directory
        at java.lang.ClassLoader$NativeLibrary.load(Native Method)
        at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadLibrary0(ClassLoader.java:1560)
        at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadLibrary(ClassLoader.java:1485)
        at java.lang.Runtime.loadLibrary0(Runtime.java:788)
        at java.lang.System.loadLibrary(System.java:834)
        at org.eclipse.swt.internal.Library.loadLibrary(Library.java:100)
        at org.eclipse.swt.internal.gtk.OS.<clinit>(OS.java:19)
        at org.eclipse.swt.internal.Converter.wcsToMbcs(Converter.java:63)
        at org.eclipse.swt.internal.Converter.wcsToMbcs(Converter.java:54)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.<clinit>(Display.java:118)
        at Main.main(Main.java:6)


BTW, I checked the permissions on that directory, and they are all accessible

So it's only an SWT problem.

Where did you get the Suse 64 bit from? We only tested against RedHat 64 bit 
at the moment.

You can get the 64bit version of Suse 9.1 for free in the following way:

download the boot.iso from their ftp server:
ftp://ftp.suse.com/pub/suse/x86_64/9.1/boot/

burn it and boot to it and put this as the installation source:
ftp://ftp.suse.com/pub/suse/x86_64/9.1/

This will perform a REAL, COMPLETE installation without having to purchase the
media.

I really encourage you to follow through with this because SUSE is the second
largest distribution of Linux (next to your choice of RH) and deserves attention.

thanks and if you could, would you please keep us updated as to whether you are
going to try this and what your results are..


Here is the quote from the readme howto:
---------------------------------------
Preparation

  o booting from CD

    Download the iso image boot/boot.iso and burn a CD with it.

Installation

  Boot from CD and at the bootpromt enter the installation source:

    linux26 install=ftp://ftp_server/directory

  Remember to substitute 'ftp_server' and 'directory' with the appropriate
  values (e.g. install=ftp://[IP-ADDRESS]/pub/suse/x86_64/9.1 if you're
  installing from the SUSE ftp server).

Same problem under Gentoo Linux with kernel 2.6.9, nptl enabled and using the
blackdown 1.4.2 or Sun JDK 1.5.0 JVM's.  Eclipse 3.0.1 works fine, 3.1M1 or
3.1M2 do not work.

Okay, my apologies, I was mistaken about the 3.1M2 build still being broken. 
3.1M2 (build 200409240800) works correctly, whereas 3.1M1 did not work.

Eclipse doesn't seem to work for me on Redhat Enterprise Linux V3 Update 2.
I've tried 3.0, 3.0.1, 3.1M2, but they all seem to have the same link problem.

Is there something special that you have to do after unzipping it?

I believe that this occurs because the VM you are using is a 32-bit binary,
which means you cannot use the 64-bit version of Eclipse, you must use the
32-bit version instead.

Billy Biggs is correct. Starting eclipse64 on a 32bit jvm ends up in the 
previously mentioned error. When starting eclipse64 with a 64 bit jvm, it 
starts with no problems whatsoever. (it runs fine on my SuSE 9.1 pro system) 
I had the same problem when trying to run eclipse64 on a 1.4.2 jdk (sun does 
not provide an AMD64 bit 1.4 jdk, only an Intel 64 Bit, which doesn't run on 
the average AMD64 bit system :-) I had no problems after installing the 
jdk1.5.0

If this is true, I think we should really detect this case and allow for a more
appropriate error message.

Mark: can you paste the URL you used to successfully install and run Sun 1.5 
for Linux AMD64?
Did you downloaded the 32 bit 1.4.2 JVM yourself or was it part of your Suse 
distribution?

Christophe, 
 
The link I used to download the 1.5 jdk is : 
 
http://192.18.97.54/ECom/EComTicketServlet/BEGINE843037CD0D0BA196843569D69EDD21F/-2147483648/613548075/1/531770/531734/613548075/2ts+/westCoastFSEND/jdk-1.5.0-oth-JPR/jdk-1.5.0-oth-JPR:12/jdk-1_5_0-linux-amd64.bin 
 
Basically, I just downloaded the latest jdk from the sun site. 
( http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/download.jsp ) I choose the binary 
distribution because usually rpm packages are made for redhat and sometimes 
this messes up my system.  
The binary extracts itself into a folder, which I just moved next to my 
current 1.4.2 jdk. I started eclipse using the -vm argument 
(./eclipse -vm /opt/java_apps/jdk1.5.0/jre/bin/java to be precise) 
 
I hope this helps you in solving this problem en closing the bug. For me it 
did the job! If you need anything more, don't hestitate to ask. I might take 
some time answering (i'ts getting a late here) but i'll try to do anything I 
can to help you guys! 
 
Greetings, Mark Smit

Christophe, 
I forgot to answer your second question. 
I also downloaded the 1.4.2 jvm from the sun site.  A little snippet from the 
eclipse 'crash'-log shows the version I used: 
eclipse.buildId=I200411050810 
java.version=1.4.2_04 
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc. 
As I said before, I used the 32bit version, since sun only provided an IA64 
version, which wouldn't install (obviously).  
I will try and install the version SuSE ships with 9.1 pro and report on it 
later.

Well, I tried the jvm SuSE ships with the 9.1 distribution. It crashes 
eclipse, and since it's an SUN jvm, I suspect it's a 32 bit compiled jvm. 
Here's the version info from the eclipse logfile : 
 
eclipse.buildId=I200411050810 
java.version=1.4.2_03 
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc. 
 
The version info, from the SuSE shipped jvm also makes me believe it's a 32 
bit compiled jvm. The version info is: 
java -version 
java version "1.4.2_04" 
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2_04-b04) 
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2_04-b04, mixed mode) 
 
The version info of the jdk1.5.0 jvm (AMD64 Arch) is: 
 
/opt/java_apps/jdk1.5.0/jre/bin/java -version 
java version "1.5.0" 
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0-b64) 
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 1.5.0-b64, mixed mode) 
 
The latter specifically shows it's '64bit-nes' which the SuSE delivered jvm 
doesn't.

Thanks Mark and Billy.

Closing this PR. We are going to add a message on the download page for AMD64 
to make it clear which JVM is required.

Would there also be a way to tell at runtime whether Eclipse is running under a
32 bit VM and somehow indicate this there as well?

I am still just surprised that this is how Eclipse would fail...
